intro: Luzula erecta subsp. nigricans, commonly known as black-tongued wood rush, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Poaceae, commonly known as the grass family, and is characterized by its tufted growth habit and slender, hollow stems. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear tiny, greenish to brownish flowers, which are typically wind-pollinated. Its leaves are grass-like, linear, and often have a bluish-green hue, contributing to its ornamental value in shady garden settings. Luzula erecta subsp. nigricans is adapted to moist, woodland environments and is often found in shaded, well-drained soils.
